Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: A Multinational Analysis of Factors that Determine the Effectiveness of COVID-19 Warning Messages

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: The Covid-19 pandemic, which emerged in late 2019, swept the globe in early 2020 causing significant problems for national health, prosperity, and welfare across many nations. Official information sources had to balance the need to provide timely information to dispel rumors against the need for accuracy. This became increasingly problematic as increasing numbers of staff became unable to work. As a consequence, unexpected and often unhelpful perceptions of risk sometimes emerged in communities. These reduced trust and confidence in public servants, first-responders, the medical and scientific communities, and each other. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) study aims to determine the stimuli that influence community understanding (norms) associated with the Covid-19 pandemic as well as attitudes towards key stakeholders and protective actions. By comparing China, which was amongst the most stringently locked-down countries, and South Korea, which issued restrictions and guidance, rather than formally locking-down, the researchers will be able to identify the stimuli that influence community risk perception and attitudinal development. The findings will have implications for how to shape disaster-related policies to be more effective. The research will also have implications for communications that better support public confidence, trust in, and compliance with key public servants such as local first responders and emergency management, and the medical and scientific communities.<br/><br/>The research design is based on the observation that, in hazardous situations, unexpected risk perceptions sometimes emerge due to conflict between observed social cues and official information. On the other hand, “emergent norms” sometimes act as relationship moderators, balancing the conflicts between community risk perception, official information, and trust in public servants. This project introduces social-norm related moderators into an established theoretical framework - the Protective Action Decision Model: PADM – in an effort to better predict protective behaviors in the context of public policies and messages. A mixed-methods approach -- relying upon both qualitative content analysis and multivariate statistical analysis of structured survey responses -- will be used test the posited moderator effects. The mixed-methods approach will limit the influence of spurious causal relationships by ensuring the analytic results are examined in relationship to rich, textual accounts provided by individuals experiencing quarantine. The two countries in the sample frame (China and South Korea) undertook a range of policy variants, which will be incorporated into the survey data set for analytic comparison and policy-relevant findings. This team will conduct surveys based upon the Protective Action Decision Model, which describes how environmental context and psychological processes together predict an individual's tendency to protect against or mitigate for risks. Specifically, the project will yield fundamental understanding about how official and unofficial messages interact to affect peoples' protective behaviors, which will have implications for how decision makers can craft more effective messages and public policies to help keep communities safer.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the early stages of the Covid-19 pandemic governments faced vast uncertainty which triggered inaccurate and inconsistent information. Unexpected and often unhelpful perceptions of risk began to emerge amongst communities in China and South Korea, which reduced trust and confidence in public servants, first-responders, and the medical and scientific communities. Accordingly, this study aimed to determine the stimuli that influenced resident?s understanding (norms) of Covid-19 and their attitudes towards key stakeholders and protective actions. Our project sought answers to the following pandemic response-related questions: (1) What are the critical factors in the warning messages that help to establish an emergent norm among residents? (2) Can the conflicts of cues and information in the environmental context determine residents? stakeholder perceptions (e.g. responsibilities, trustworthiness, and expertise)? Are different levels of established emergent norms moderating this determining relationship? (3) Are the emergent norms and stakeholder perceptions facilitating protective actions (e.g. personal protection measures, social distancing, and societal responsibilities) and promoting positive attitudes (e.g. family values)?

After refining the theoretical model using archived structured interviews and the literature of social norms and risk communication, we (re)introduced two constructs (information consistency and resident emergent norms) to tailor the Protective Action Decision Model (PADM) for pandemic usage in order to answer the research questions. We then developed and validated quantitative survey tools to sample two target populations ? Chinese and South Koreans ? to determine their unique and common risk communication strategies. In total, we collected 1600 effective responses (800 in each country) and analyzed them using a variety of statistical methods.

The findings demonstrated that the information content related to personal protective measures (e.g., masks and gloves, etc.) was a significant predictor of resident?s emergent norms during Covid-19. Second, the data supported our hypothesis that the consistency of information from governments and other sources was a significant predictor of resident?s perception of stakeholders. This effect was the strongest when both PADM norms (pre-decision processes and threat perceptions) were low. Namely, when (1) the two normative constructs in the traditional PADM function together and (2) when residents have not yet established a strong emergent norm. These effects increase the consistency of information between government and other sources yielding the greatest boost in resident?s perception of government stakeholder expertise, trustworthiness, and responsibility (stakeholder perceptions). Additionally, (3) we observed the highest stakeholder perceptions when the information consistency and both normative constructs were at their maximum values. Finally, the findings indicated that resident?s norms (i.e., pre- and during-lockdown attention and threat perceptions) and stakeholder perceptions could positively explain their attitudes toward the necessity of lockdown and the satisfaction of their lives during the lockdown. The reported protective actions indicated that stakeholder perceptions remained positive, which explains their actions. However, the findings suggested a negative relationship between the norms (i.e., exposure, comprehension, and threat perceptions) and reported protective actions. This is likely because residents with higher levels of norms tended to stay home as much as possible and, therefore, had less need to adopt the protective measures advocated by the government.

The findings update the PADM through the inclusion of the prolonged exposure to risk experienced during pandemics, which extends the formation period of social norms and perceptions. Moreover, the utilized research methods can assist researchers in better defining the boundary of communities as a unit of analysis, which can detect informal and latent resident groups and help to measure their perceptual and behavioral outcomes. The findings also provide valuable guidance for governments and decision-makers in targeting and tailoring warning messages to the varying social norms and levels of risk perception of the residents they serve. Strategies can, therefore, prioritize different stages of a pandemic to promote compliance and influence public relations. Consequently, the outcomes of this study also provide a valuable resource for the teaching and practice of warning and informing during pandemics.
